title: Can you believe in God but not religion? - Quora

response.answer_text: Certainly. According to many recent demographic polls, in the United States, the number of people who profess no religious affiliation at all is increasing. And, many of them (called by demographers the “nones”) do believe in God. They simply do not actively practice any formal religion. But, there is certainly no requirement to be religious in order to believe in God. For that matter, there is no requirement to believe in God to be religious. There also seems to be a growing interest in spirituality which can be practiced with or without a formal religious setting. So many people who engage in some form of spiritual practice, such as meditation or yoga, do believe in God. The American Architect Frank Lloyd Wright provided a famous response to the question of whether he was religious or believed in God. In an interview with Mike Wallace he said that whereas many people spell God “G-O-D,” he (Wright) put a capital “N” on Nature and called that God. So, there are any number of variations on the question of belief and the question of religious practice. The Dalai Lama once suggested that in an ideal world there would be as many religions as there are people. For many people, religion and the formal practice of it provide a great deal of comfort, community, and spiritual benefits. For others, they receive these benefits in other ways without the formality of religion. Benjamin Franklin once wrote an interesting parable on religious tolerance which seems apropos here: There was once an officer, a worthy man, named Montresor, who was very ill. His parish priest, thinking he would die, advised him to make his peace with God, so that he would be received into Paradise. “I don’t feel much uneasiness on that score,” said Montresor; “for last night I had a vision which set me entirely at rest.” “What vision did you have?” asked the good priest. “I was,” he said, “at the Gate of Paradise with a crowd of people who wanted to enter. And St. Peter asked each of them which religion he belonged to. One answered, ‘I am a Roman Catholic.’ ‘Very well,’ said St. Peter; ‘come in and take your place over there among the Catholics.’ Another said he belonged to the Anglican Church. ‘Very well,’ said St. Peter; ‘come in and take your place over there among the Anglicans.’ [And so on for many other denominations.] Finally, he asked me what my religion was. ‘Alas!’ I replied, ‘unfortunately, poor Jacques Montresor belongs to none at all.’ ‘That’s a pity,’ said the Saint. ‘But enter anyway and take any place you wish.’

Absolutely, in my opinion. Think of God as sitting in the middle of a forest. You are standing just outside the perimeter. You need to figure out a way to the center. And once you meet the creator, you must be in a position to understand God and divine actions. The idea is to make you capable of connecting with God through your journey. There are many ways to get there. Religion is a well-trodden road that some great explorer laid out.  It looks like a clear easy path. But there are demands. Traditions set by the explorer as per her/his knowledge. Some conditions that you must follow to progress on the path. Obstacles will stand like pieces of puzzle in front of you and test you. They will say: ‘Follow this practice or else hitherto shall thou come, but no further.’ Some of these tests make you stronger and a better person. But some are plain deceitful. They threaten you with the stick of divine retribution and add nothing to your journey. Over the time, the latter type of roadblocks have increased in number. In the current age have far too many distractions from this path to God, so we take longer to get there. The fear of not being able to complete our journey makes us respect these superficial tests. Religions are not as pristine as they used to be. They now come with strings attached. Then there are paths like these:  These are not easy. You have to make your own way. You fall, you get up, you think of God who’s always there with you. These struggles are real. They are your struggles. Through your perseverance, you adapt some practices that work for you. These are your traditions. Often, these might be the same practices that people on the religious path took. But you agree another person may not face the same hurdles because everyone’s spiritual journey is different. If you follow the second path, are you an atheist? No. You believe in God. You see the mechanisms of divine all around you. You understand the reason behind the pain you suffer. You might even have a greater insight into God than the wayfarers on religious paths. But you chose a different path, a different institution to reach God. So you don’t believe in the religions propagated by the famous explorers. You don’t believe the tests set by someone else. *All roads lead to God. That’s the truth and beauty of existence. If you are determined, strong and adventurous enough to carve your own path, you will find God at the end of it, regardless of adherence to any religion. *Update: All roads lead to God, if you believe in God that is. Atheists, I understand, believe in a certain set of moral principles and humane logic which guide them on through life. So when in doubt you come back to these principles. Believers flock back to God in the same way. We are simply discussing the need for the institution of religion as a pre-requisite to believing in God here. This answer doesn't pit atheism with theism. Honestly, I have dabbled in both. My decisions are based on logic and humane considerations too. But in my worst moments, I do pray inwardly. So it would be hypocritical of me to call myself an Atheist. I wasn't taught that my Gods are punitive. So I feel no stigma attached to calling myself a theist either. Can you believe in friendship without conversation? In progress without organization? Relationship with God is absolutely the only place in life that we even consider such a question. It’s like saying, “Can I believe in God without having to participate in anything He does or have to be excessively bothered by Him? Anything we do (at least anything about which we’re serious) involves structure. Video games have rules of engagement. Gaming clusters have rules of conduct. If we go out sailing , surfing, playing baseball, all of these things have rules, conventions, relationships. If we want to improve at them, we learn to follow—and mature into wanting to follow—these. Otherwise, we’ll never get anywhere with them. I have found tat people who try to oppose “religion” and “relationship” don’t really understand what they’re saying. They equate “religion” with a collection of empty observances that are without life. But that isn’t religion. The word they’re looking for is accidie, (OX-ee-DEE), just sort of a going-through-the-numbers coasting. Religion, real religion, is Spirit-filled and vital. It is an adventure of growth in Christ. Religion is not opposed to relationship with God—it’s what defines it. You can certainly “believe in God.” You can believe that water is wet. But unless you jump in and learn to swim, it won’t do you any good. It’s the act of commitment to Christ that puts you in touch with the Grace by which we are saved. And commitment is not merely believing the water is wet: it’s learning how swimming is done, and growing in the desire—and doing the work—to get ever better at it. This is not done through a collection of empty observances, but by a dynamic relationship with the water.

response.answer_text: Definitely, you can. It depends on who/what you think God is. If you think God is a man in the sky with a long white beard and a golden staff, a jealous and egotistical being who freaks out when you do not worship him or obey “his word,” a vengeful being who cannot wait to condemn you and throw you in “hell” for your sins, then by all means go ahead and believe in/adhere to religion.  Surprisingly, most atheists I’ve come across seem to think the above defines God. For some reason, they always fail to look beyond religious definitions of God, and that is probably why they don’t believe there is a God, because they think the idea is absurd, which it is, when you only look at it from a religious perspective. But if you are an out-of-the-box thinker, then you will realize that the definition of God given above is unrealistic, to put it mildly. You will realize that God is far, far, far above what a lot of religions make “him” out to be. You will also realize that we humans at this stage of evolution have a very limited perception of “him.” Personally, I do not subscribe to any religion, but I believe there is a supreme/supernatural being who is behind our existence, call him God or whatever you like. And no, I do not believe that this being cares about our religion, or whether we worship “him” or not. So, there you have it. You can believe in God but not religion.

Of course. I fit that description in all but one respect: for me, belief is the wrong word. Belief implies accepting something as true on someone else’s say-so. The word I use is awareness. It’s my own; no one ever told me to have it. It’s just there, and has been for as long as I can remember. It was never not there. I don’t come from a religious family and I’ve never been religious myself. I described my awareness to my mother when I was very young, and she said, “Oh, that’s God.” I said “Oh ok,” and went about the rest of my day. I’d heard the word before, and as with so many other words in those days, I was pleased to have a concept associated with it. All part of a non-religious kid’s learning process. I did make a point of checking out the world’s main religions later on, and found inspiring, sublime, and incredibly beautiful ideas, art, and poetry in every one. Say what you want about religion, it does express the very best in us. If I met someone visiting here from another star and this being asked me, “What’s the best way for me to learn about humanity?” I’d say, “Study our religions. Leave the science, technology, history, philosophy for later. They’re very important, but they won’t make complete sense unless you do this first.”

If by religion you mean formal or organized religion, yes. The two concepts are not necessarily linked. The concept of having a belief in god while eschewing formal or organized religion grew after the Enlightenment, as the concepts of individual liberty and personal conscience challenged authoritarian religious dogma. The distinction is probably as old as religion itself, though as far as evidence for early religious beliefs most has to do with public ritual and religious practice. It appears formal or organized religion was a unifying factor in many early societies, though belief in specific deities was probably preceded by ritualistic behaviors not necessarily connected with divinity. The first written evidence of religion was from Sumer in Mesopotamia and dates about 5,500 years ago. However judging by archeological finds at burial sites and the discovery of talismans and statues in excavated settlements, ritualistic behavior and collective religious beliefs seemed to have arisen in the first part of the Upper Paleolithic period, though some think it could have been earlier and even practiced by other hominids In my opinion, most likely there have always been individuals who have sought their own connection with what they considered to be divine or sacred, apart from public ritual or collective affirmation. Some accept and enjoy collective ritual and public affirmation while others prefer solo contemplation.
